title: 106_s59
content: The "Regulatory Right-to-Know Act of 1999" promotes public awareness of the costs and benefits of Federal regulatory programs, increases Government accountability, and enhances the quality of such programs and rules. The Act defines terms such as "benefit" and "cost" in relation to the effects of rules, emphasizing social, health, safety, environmental, economic, and distributional impacts. The Act defines key terms such as "Director," "Major rule," and "Program element" in relation to rulemaking processes. The Act defines key terms related to rulemaking processes, including "Director," "Major rule," and "Program element." SEC. 4 states the requirement for an accounting statement. The President must annually submit an accounting statement to Congress, detailing the costs and benefits of Federal regulatory programs, analyzing their impacts, and providing recommendations for reform. The Director is required to quantify the net benefits or costs of regulatory programs and provide recommendations for reform. Accounting statements must cover costs and benefits for the 4 fiscal years preceding the report submission, with the option to revise previous estimates. Before submitting a report to Congress, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget must provide public notice, allow for comments, and consult with the Comptroller General. After considering feedback, an appendix addressing public and peer review comments will be included in the report. Additionally, guidance from the Office of Management and Budget will be provided. SEC. 6. GUIDANCE FROM THE OFFICE OF MANAGEMENT AND BUDGET. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will issue guidelines to standardize measures of costs and benefits for agencies within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The format of accounting statements will also be standardized. The Director will review agency submissions for compliance with these guidelines. SEC. 7. PEER REVIEW. SEC. 7. PEER REVIEW. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will arrange for independent peer review of guidelines and accounting statements by a public policy research organization before finalization. Peer review comments will be used in preparing the final documents, and the process is not subject to the Federal Advisory Committee Act.
